text: now mole fraction is simply another way
of finding the concentration of the
solution it's represented by the letter
X and the formula reads moles of solute
divided by moles of solute plus moles of
solid so you're dividing by the total
number of moles now this formula gives
you the mole fraction of solute you can
also find the mole fraction of the
solvent by simply changing the top to
the moles of solvent divided by the
total number of moles
now notice mole fraction is a fraction
you divide moles by moles which means
it's unitless now let's try a problem
using mole fraction
the problem tells us that we have 250
grams of sodium chloride and 1500 grams
of h2o
now notice h2o is our solvent and NaCl
is our solid now our goal is to find a
mole fraction of NaCl and h2o now the
first step is to find the number of
moles of sodium chloride and the number
of moles of h2o in order to find the
number of moles we have to find a
molecular weight of each compound to
find the molecular weight of NaCl we
have to add the atomic weight of sodium
and atomic weight of chlorine that gives
us 23.0 grams per mole plus 35 point
five grams per mole gives us 58 point
five grams per mole this is our
molecular weight now we take our weight
250 grams of sodium chloride divide that
by the molecular weight and that gives
us the number of moles four point two
seven moles of sodium chloride found
within the solution now we follow the
same exact steps for water since there
are 2 H molecules we have to multiply
two times the atomic weight of H which
is 1 so 2 grams per mole plus 16 grams
per mole gives us 18 grams per mole so
the molecular weight of water is 18
grams per mole next we take the weight
1500 grams per mole of water divide that
by 18 grams per mole and we get 83.3
moles of water found within the solution
finally to find the mole fraction we use
the formula the mole fraction of h2o is
the number of moles of h2o
divided by the total number of moles
gives us 83.3 divided by the total
number of moles which is approximately
zero point nine five to find the mole
fraction for sodium chloride
we follow the same procedure but now on
top we put the number of moles of nacl
so for point two seven divided by the
total number of moles gives us zero
point zero five now because mole
fraction is a fraction we divide moles
by moles the answers are unitless
